Forced segregation is NOT the same as forced diversity because while the former has likelihood to create more tensions and negative stereotypes between groups, the latter closes the gap by familiarising people from each group. How absurd would it be if you keep believing "X food is the most delicious food for me" and hesitates to eat something else recommended to you, without even tasting it a few times? Sometimes, the taste of the food or a music you hear grows on you with time. You can argue that music/food doesn't have free will so it doesn't become an issue , but the issue is your decisions can indirectly impact others lives living in society. No matter how much you want to believe otherwise, we are all indirectly depended on each other in a society. Society functions best as collective. If you become too independent and selfish, it'll only create major imbalances in societal structure leading to its downfall. MGTOW, feminism, incels all are consequences of an imbalanced societal structure. The less we start caring about others issues, more and more problems further ensues. As a progressive society, it should cater to the concerns of everyone contributing equally to the society. That's how you maintain harmony and peace in a society.

I think it's normal for people to have biases; especially, when it comes to choices for romantic partners. Nobody can or should force people to date the people they don't fancy. However, you should question why you find some people attractive and others not, especially when the source of attraction isn't based on a person's characters but a person's race. If you look at what is considered beautiful for both male and female, the standard of beauty is people with Caucasian physical features. For proof, see people on TV, movies, magazines, billboards, etc., you'll see mostly white people, and life imitates arts. There is a long tradition in media to discriminate against people of color--I haven't seen an Asian man in a leading-roled superheroes yet, and I'm sill waiting. Although I'm very happy to see a black male lead for the latest Star Wars. As a result, people who consume mass media bought into t he racism perpetuated by the media, believing the standard of beauty spoon fed by the media. It is not a simple case of colored drinking fountain or bathroom anymore. This is 2 018; racism is a lot more subtle. It may seem like "preference", but it is in fact racism when you exclude a whole race from your consideration. That said, you will and should date who you want to date. However, I would challenge you to intentionally look for beauty in people of the races you may have judged as unattractive. You don't need to date or even talk to them. You just have to look for beauty in them. Chances are you will find some people of the race attractive--it is impossible to find all peopl e of the race attractive, eve n for the race of your preference. You should make up your own preference and don't allow other people, especially the media, to influence you in such an important choice of your life like people you date or marry because I don't believe the media industry have your interests at heart. Besides, when you see more beauty in the world, you are the one who benefits from seeing all the beauty.

commentThread.commentText: As a white dude, I have to admit I find it difficult to navigate the dating scene in terms of racial preferences and such. Like, on one hand, I have dated men of multiple races, from white to Indian to African American and Latino. In that, racial issues where I don't necessarily understand their experiences as men of color in America have occasionally popped up. While I have never not dated someone because of thei r race, I have to be aware that they can't come to me, talk about their experiences that day in that sense and have me understand it the way a person of color would be able to understand it. Similarly, cultural differences between my suburban white experience and their experiences have led to miscommunications. I personally am willing to put in that work and understand those experiences and try to be there for that person, but you can't expect everyone to do that. Similarly, people of other races do have these " my race only" dating sites and thats permitted, often because they want to date someone who has similar cultural experiences to them. I don't think its a problem for white people to do the same thing. While I personally wouldn't care enough that my SO is of a cert ain race to make a profile on any website dedicated to that race exclusively, I think that other people having those perferences is perfectly fine.

Yeah, sounds perfectly fine to me! It sounds like you're trying to tell people that they MUST have these wide open preferences, but that's contrary to very definition of the word 'preferences'. A preference is a discrimination (another word that's been boogeymanned) of things you do not enjoy, find safe, or want to partake in. For example, I do not like hard drugs, thus I discriminate against drugs and my preference is someone who is not a drug user. Otherwise the relationship would be off to a very rocky start. So yes, there is nothing wrong with having discriminatory tastes against things you do not enjoy or find contrary to your own lifestyle and principles. And to address racial preference directly, I will say that human beings are very tribal in nature. Even in Europe, a place that many people do not affiliate with tribal structures, was VERY tribal not a few hundred years ago. To me, it makes far more sense to want to seek out someone who looks more like you, talks and sounds more like you, has the same tastes in cultural things as you, shared the same interests as you such as cultural similarities. For example, I would find it difficult to share Christian ideals if I had a Muslim wife. Granted that's a religious difference, the same can be said for other cultural differences. I find your argument to be hypocritical in which you say people absolutely must seek out people of other races to find compatibility, yet the most fundamental traits of compatibility are cultural traits, and even racial traits in some regards. This is why we have Latino neighborhoods, black neighborhoods, Asian neighborhoods, etc. let alone markets that are geared towards certain races and cultures, and other institutions that are for or attract members of certain races and cultures. It seems that the vast majority of people who support these ideas that we should mix or that we must are mostly white people, and that most other people (except some in th e black community perhaps) don't even remotely feel this way.
